text: Why do companies decide to host their blog on a separate domain? And what are the benefits of doing this? I’m trying to convince a company that has five different websites to centralise their content efforts, but it’s falling on deaf ears so far.

elements.text: Why do companies decide to host their blog on a separate domain? And what are the benefits of doing this? I’m trying to convince a company that has five different websites to centralise their content efforts, but it’s falling on deaf ears so far.

text:
This may be a controversial point coming from the editor in charge of style guides… but I’d say go right ahead and break the rule if it makes sense :slightly_smiling_face:

Context: our style guide at Hotjar directs us to spell out numbers below 10—BUT “Seven ways to do X” as a title is not very catchy at-a-glance or intuitive → so I encourage my writers to be mindful of the rule in general, but break it when it helps a reader make sense of a title.

elements.text: This may be a controversial point coming from the editor in charge of style guides… but I’d say go right ahead and break the rule if it makes sense

Context: our style guide at Hotjar directs us to spell out numbers below 10—BUT “Seven ways to do X” as a title is not very catchy at-a-glance or intuitive → so I encourage my writers to be mindful of the rule in general, but break it when it helps a reader make sense of a title.

text: I inherited <http://dispatch.m.io|dispatch.m.io> which was separate from <http://m.io|m.io> - our website (sales landing page, pricing etc) gets about about 10% of the traffic that the blog domain does.

elements.text: I inherited
dispatch.m.io
which was separate from
m.io
- our website (sales landing page, pricing etc) gets about about 10% of the traffic that the blog domain does.

text: I think sometimes it’s down to tech issues. Some CMS’s don’t support subfolders (e.g. <http://name.com/blog|name.com/blog>), and those that do, often require a bit more upfront work to setup. We moved all of our content over to the main domain at the start of 2019. We done a lot of research into it and generally it seems better for search to have everything on the main domain/subfolders. Sometimes content can also be split across domains depending on the audience it serves too.

text:
Companies often go for subdomains or completely separate domains because of technical limitations, as <@UPWK0KJE9> mentioned.

10/10 it’s best to have the blog on the main domain, the blog helps the main site rank better and vice versa.

elements.text: Companies often go for subdomains or completely separate domains because of technical limitations, as

mentioned.

10/10 it’s best to have the blog on the main domain, the blog helps the main site rank better and vice versa.

text: For instance, that the chosen CMS doesn’t support a blog out-of-the-box, and that it would have to be custom built and would be shit, and take ages.

elements.text: For instance, that the chosen CMS doesn’t support a blog out-of-the-box, and that it would have to be custom built and would be shit, and take ages.

text: I'm not super technical so can't get deep into the 'why' but a lot of hosting companies also won't support a blog on a subfolder (e.g. <http://name.com/blog|name.com/blog>). We had to switch from WPEngine to Kinsta to make it happen and even then it took a bit of work from our engineers to sort it all out.

text:
you might have your app running on <http://domain.com|domain.com>, which makes it much easier to setup your blog on <http://blog.domain.com|blog.domain.com>, otherwise you have to integrate the blog into a subfolder into your app which means probably either using a headless content api like contentful or a routing service like <http://fly.io|fly.io>.

if your site on the domain is running on something like wordpress, it's trivial to add the blog. then your app will likely live on a subdomain like <http://app.domain.com|app.domain.com> and that's cool because your app isn't indexed on search.

however a lot of devs don't necessarily start out thinking about the blog/this which creates the pain later of putting the blog in a subfolder

text:
It sounds like someone who's read a couple articles about writing and remembered 1 point and now won't go against that point _no matter what_. Writing takes nuance! I would show him examples of websites when "We" works beautifully well and see how he feels about it.

Unravelling can be a bit tricky IMO.

no matter what

. Writing takes nuance! I would show him examples of websites when "We" works beautifully well and see how he feels about it.

Unravelling can be a bit tricky IMO.

text: I think "7" catches the eye faster than "seven". When you use the numeral it looks distinct and different from the words.

text:
One of my personal projects is co-hosting a Taylor Swift podcast. We're about to break 8,000 monthly listeners this month and have about 75 Patreon subscribers.

My question is...is having 8,000 monthly listeners enough to warrant reaching out to brands for ad sponsorships? We've done a few campaigns with one sponsor in the past, but they reached out to us -- we've never actually done outreach before.

Or would it be more worthwhile to just keep plugging away at building our Patreon audience?

elements.text:
One of my personal projects is co-hosting a Taylor Swift podcast. We're about to break 8,000 monthly listeners this month and have about 75 Patreon subscribers.

My question is...is having 8,000 monthly listeners enough to warrant reaching out to brands for ad sponsorships? We've done a few campaigns with one sponsor in the past, but they reached out to us -- we've never actually done outreach before.

Or would it be more worthwhile to just keep plugging away at building our Patreon audience?

text: Hey <@UJ4A0H534> happy to chat via DM if that’ll be useful. I see <@UJJFDTN8G> has already shared some great advice and I know he’s had some great success growing his company blog using this report as a benchmark (now far exceeded :muscle:) in terms of the research I put together I’d say <http://ek-byford.com/saas-content-marketing/#saas-blog-performance|this section> will be most relevant to you, and to pay more attention to the numbers for the fastest-growing companies than the “biggest”.

attachments.title: The State of SaaS Content Marketing 2019 - Emily Byford
attachments.text: Does content marketing work in SaaS? I've analysed 500 of the world's biggest SaaS companies, to uncover their content marketing strategies.
attachments.fallback: Emily Byford: The State of SaaS Content Marketing 2019 - Emily Byford

text: as a regular podcast sponsor, our minimum is 5k, our ideal is 10k, so I'd say you're well within range to seek sponsors!

text: You can definitely get a sponsor, my suggestion is niche audiences like niche brands. As in, partner with someone small and local and it’ll feel like a more genuine connection than a run of the mill podcast sponsorship

text: Agree with everything but do you really want the article to appear as a snippet? If it ranked on #1 or #2 before check the previous stats to see if they were worse than the traffic/leads the snippet brings
